questions: What preventive services are covered in VA?
What health care services does VA cover?
What does VA health care cover?
Is genetic testing covered by the VA?
What preventive care is covered by the VA?
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "We cover preventive care services, like:

*   Health exams (including gender-specific exams)
*   Health education (including nutrition education)
*   Immunization against infectious diseases (like flu shots)
*   Counseling on genetic diseases (diseases that run in families)"

For more information, go to the [About VA health benefits](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits) page.

questions: What other medical services will VA cover to support my treatment?
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "We may cover services that your VA primary care provider concludes you need to support your treatment (called ancillary services), like:

*   Tests used to diagnose health conditions, including blood work, X-rays, and ultrasounds
*   Therapy and rehabilitation services, including physical therapy, vision rehab, and therapy for traumatic brain injury
*   Additional services, including prosthetic items, audiology (care for hearing loss), and radiation oncology (cancer care)"

For more information, go to the [About VA health benefits](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits) page.

questions: How do I refill a prescription?
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "We’ll fill prescriptions by a non-VA community provider only if you meet all these requirements.

All of these must be true:

*   You’re enrolled in VA health care
*   You have an assigned VA primary care provider
*   You’ve given your VA provider your medical records from your non-VA provider
*   Your VA provider agrees with the prescription"

For more information, go to the [About VA health benefits](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits) page.

questions: How do I apply for benefits?

value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "
* Find out if you’re eligible for VA health care benefits 
* Gather the information listed below that you’ll need to fill out an Application for Health Benefits (VA Form 10-10EZ) You'll need this information: 
* Social Security numbers for you, your spouse, and your qualified dependents 
* Your military discharge papers (DD214 or other separation documents) 
* Insurance card information for all insurance companies that cover you, including any coverage provided through a spouse or significant other. This includes Medicare, private insurance, or insurance from your employer.  
* Gross household income from the previous calendar year for you, your spouse, and your dependents."

For more information, go to the [How to apply for VA health care](https://www.va.gov/health-care/how-to-apply) page.

questions: Does the VA help with closing costs?
Does a loan cover closing costs?
Does the VA help with down payment
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "A VA-backed purchase loan often offers:

*   No down payment as long as the sales price isn’t higher than the home’s appraised value (the value set for the home after an expert reviews the property)
*   Better terms and interest rates than other loans from private banks, mortgage companies, or credit unions (also called lenders)
*   The ability to borrow up to the Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac conforming loan limit on a no-down-payment loan in most areas—and more in some high-cost counties."

For more information, go to the [Purchase loan](https://www.va.gov/housing-assistance/home-loans/loan-types/purchase-loan) page.

*   You have at least one day of unexpired GI Bill entitlement, and
*   You’re accepted into a program by a VA-approved training provider"
For more information, go to the [Veterans technology education courses](https://www.va.gov/education/about-gi-bill-benefits/how-to-use-benefits/vettec-high-tech-program) page.

questions: How can I get a work-study?
Am I eligible to get a work-study
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "You may be eligible to take part in our work-study program if you meet all of these requirements.

All of these must be true:

*   You’re enrolled at least three-quarter time in a college degree, vocational, or professional program, and
*   You have found an open job either at a nearby VA facility or in a VA-related role at your school, and
*   You can finish the work-study contract while you still qualify for education benefits, and
*   You’re using an approved VA education benefits program to pay for your education or training"

For more information, go to the [Work study](https://www.va.gov/education/about-gi-bill-benefits/how-to-use-benefits/work-study) page.

questions: How do apply for yellow ribbon program?
Am I eligible for the Yellow Ribbon Program?
Is my school part of yellow ribbon?
Can I apply for yellow ribbon?
How do I get yellow ribbon?
value.answer:
Here is what VA.gov says: "You may be eligible for this program if you and your school meet these requirements. You must qualify for the Post-9/11 GI Bill at the 100% benefit level And at least one of these must be true: 
* You served at least 36 months on active duty (either all at once or with breaks in service) and were honorably discharged, or 
* You received a Purple Heart on or after September 11, 2001, and were honorably discharged after any amount of service, or 
* You served at least 30 continuous days (all at once, without a break) on or after September 11, 2001, and were discharged or released from active duty for a service-connected disability, or 
* You’re an active-duty service member who has served at least 36 months on active duty (either all at once or with breaks in service), or 
* You’re a spouse using the transferred benefits of an active-duty service member who has served at least 36 months on active duty, or 
* You’re a dependent child using benefits transferred by a Veteran, or 
* You’re a Fry Scholar Learn about the Fry Scholarship Learn about transferring Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits Your school must meet certain requirements All of these must be true: 
* Your school is an institution of higher learning, and 
* Your school offers the Yellow Ribbon Program, and 
* Your school hasn’t offered the Yellow Ribbon benefit to more than the maximum number of students in their agreement with us, and 
* Your school has certified your enrollment with us and provided Yellow Ribbon Program information Find schools that offer the Yellow Ribbon Program this year"

For more information, go to the [Yellow Ribbon Program](https://www.va.gov/education/about-gi-bill-benefits/post-9-11/yellow-ribbon-program) page.

questions: How do I know my priority group?
value.answer:
When you apply for VA health care, VA assigns you to 1 of 8 priority groups. This system helps to make sure that Veterans who need care right away can get signed up quickly. It also helps VA ensure high-quality care to all Veterans enrolled in VA health care program.

[Find out more about priority groups, how they work, and how they may affect you](https://www.va.gov/health-care/eligibility/priority-groups/)

questions: What types of tests can I get paid back for through the GI Bill?
Get paid back for test fees
value.answer:
You can use part of your GI Bill entitlement to cover the cost of specific tests you need to take to become a licensed or certified professional—or to apply for college or a training course. We only cover tests approved for the GI Bill under this benefit.

Before you take any tests, go to the [Get paid back for test fees](https://www.va.gov/education/about-gi-bill-benefits/how-to-use-benefits/test-fees/) page to find out what's approved

questions: I need to pay my copay bill
Make a payment on my copay
How do I pay my copay by phone?
How do I mail a copay payment?
Can I pay my copay in person?
value.answer:
You need to pay your full VA copay bill balance by the due date on your billing statement to avoid late charges, interest, or collection actions. Check how much you owe for medical service and prescription copays at each VA facility.

Go to the [Review and Pay Your VA Copay bill](https://www.va.gov/health-care/pay-copay-bill/) page to:

- Review your bills and current balances.

- Find out how you can pay online, by phone, mail, or in person.
- Learn about financial hardship assistance programs such as repayment plans, debt relief, or copay exemptions.
- See how you can dispute your copay charges.

questions: How do I apply for TRICARE?

value.answer:
If you’re the spouse, surviving spouse, dependent child, or family caregiver of a Veteran or service member, you may qualify for health care benefits. In some instances, you may also be eligible for health care benefits due to a disability related to your Veteran’s service.

Go to the [Health care for spouses, dependents, and family caregivers](https://www.va.gov/health-care/family-caregiver-benefits/) page to find out if you qualify for the following health care programs:

- The Civilian Health and Medical Program of the Department of Veteran Affairs (CHAMPVA).

- The Program of Comprehensive Assistance for Family Caregivers.

- The Camp Lejeune Family Member Program.

- The Children of Women Vietnam Veterans Health Care Benefits Program.

- Pharmacy benefits.

questions: Can I get free VA health care as a Veteran?
How can I get free health care?
value.answer:
You can get free VA health care for any illness or injury that we determine is related to your military service (called “service-connected”).

We also provide certain other services for free. These include readjustment counseling and related mental health services, care for military sexual trauma (MST) issues, and a registry health exam to determine if you’re at risk of health problems linked to your military service.

 You may qualify for additional free VA health care depending on your income, disability rating, or other special eligibility factors. To learn more, go to the [Your health care costs](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits/cost-of-care/) page.

questions: Will I need to pay for any of my care, tests, or medications?
How much does VA health care cost?
value.answer:
You may need to pay a fixed amount for some types of care, tests, and medications you receive from a VA health care provider or an approved community health care provider to treat conditions not related to your service. This is called a copay (short for “copayment”).

Whether or not you’ll need to pay copays - and how much you’ll pay - depends on your disability rating, income level, military service record, and which of our eight priority groups we assign you to when you enroll in VA health care.

To learn more, go to the [Your health care costs](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits/cost-of-care/) page.

questions: How does VA determine whether I'll need to pay copays based on my income?
Will my income change my copay?
Does my income affect my copay?
Does my salary change my health coverage?
How does VA determine whether I'll need to pay copays based on my income?
Do I have to report a new salary?
Do I have to provide financial information?
value.answer:
If you’re not already receiving VA disability compensation or pension payments, or don’t have special eligibility factors (like receiving the Medal of Honor), we’ll ask for information about your income as part of our health care enrollment process. This is called an income assessment or financial assessment (formerly known as a means test). We’re required by law to collect this information.

To learn more, go to the [Your health care costs](https://www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits/cost-of-care/) page.

questions: What information do I need to provide?
What do I need to provide to get health care?
value.answer:
You’ll need to provide your gross household income for the previous year. Your gross household income means the total amount of money you—and anyone living with you in your home—earned within one calendar year, before taxes. This includes your income from work as well as any other sources, like money you may have taken from a retirement fund or income from the sale of a house. If you have a spouse, partner, or dependent child who also contributes income to your family, you’ll need to include this income in your application.

To learn more, go to the [Your health care costs](https: //www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits/cost-of-care/) page.

questions: What is the current income limit?
What income do I need to have to have free health coverage?
Find out what happens if the IRS and SSA information shows you have income above our limits
value.answer: Go to the [Annual Income Limits  -  Health Benefits](https://www.va.gov/healthbenefits/apps/explorer/AnnualIncomeLimits/HealthBenefits) page to learn more about VA National Income Limits for medical benefits and prescriptions.

questions: Once I’m enrolled, do I need to update my income information every year?
Do I need to update my income information?
Update my income information every year
value.answer:
This depends on your situation:

- If you completed a financial assessment to find out if you were eligible for cost-free medications or for beneficiary travel pay (but not for free VA health care), you’ll need to provide updated income information each year.

- If we determine you’re eligible for free VA health care because your household income is below our income limit, you don’t have to provide updated income information each year.

Even when not required, we encourage you to report changes in your income. It’s also important to let us know about changes to your personal information (like your address, phone number, dependents, or other health insurance).

To learn more, go to the [Your health care costs](https: //www.va.gov/health-care/about-va-health-benefits/cost-of-care/) page.

questions: I don't have anywhere to go
I need a place to crash tonight
I need a place to sleep
I don't have anywhere to live
I am about to become homeless
How do I help the homeless
value.answer:
Veterans who are homeless or at imminent risk of becoming homeless can:

- Call or visit their local [VA Medical Center](https://www.va.gov/directory/guide/home.asp?isflash=1) or [Community Resource and Referral Center](https://www.va.gov/HOMELESS/Crrc.asp) where VA staff are ready to help.

- Veterans and their families may also call 1-877-4AID-VET [(1-877-424-3838)](tel:+18774243838) to access VA services.

- Explore [www.va.gov/homeless](https://www.va.gov/homeless/index.asp) to learn about [VA programs](https://www.va.gov/HOMELESS/about_homeless_programs.asp) for homeless veterans and share that information with others.

If you have access to a phone or the internet, please call your closest VA medical center before visiting. These steps are necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

You can find more information and resources by visiting the [Veterans Experiencing Homelessness](https://www.va.gov/homeless/) page.
